summary: This FBI 302 report documents an interview conducted on August 21, 2019, with a Federal Bureau of Prisons psychiatrist, Dr. [REDACTED], regarding her interactions with and assessment of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) prior to his death. The report details Epstein's statements about suicide, the psychiatric unit's procedures, and notes that a change to his will would have triggered a review of his mental state.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased inmate at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) who was interviewed by Dr. [REDACTED] on July 23, 2019, for a suicide risk assessment. He stated he was 'too much of a coward' to commit suicide.

persons.name: Dr. [REDACTED]
persons.context: A BOP staff psychiatrist interviewed by FBI agents and prosecutors. She conducted a suicide risk assessment on Epstein on July 23, 2019, and described the MCC's procedures and her clinical findings.

connections.description: Dr. [REDACTED] was the staff psychiatrist who conducted a suicide risk assessment on inmate Jeffrey Epstein at the MCC on July 23, 2019.

events.title: Epstein's Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: Dr. [REDACTED] met with Jeffrey Epstein at the MCC and conducted a suicide risk assessment. Epstein reportedly stated he was 'too much of a coward' to commit suicide, that he 'doesn't like pain,' and that suicide goes against his Jewish religion.

events.title: FBI Interview of BOP Psychiatrist
events.description: FBI agents and Assistant United States Attorneys interviewed Dr. [REDACTED], the BOP psychiatrist, regarding her assessment and interactions with Jeffrey Epstein prior to his death.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), Southern District of New York
New York, New York, United States
keyFacts: Dr. [REDACTED], a BOP psychiatrist, conducted a suicide risk assessment on Jeffrey Epstein on July 23, 2019.
Epstein told the psychiatrist he was 'too much of a coward' to commit suicide, 'doesn't like pain,' and that suicide goes against his Jewish religion.
The psychiatric staff's routine review of Epstein's file yielded no factors that would have placed him back on suicide watch.

Dr. [REDACTED] stated that if her department had been notified Epstein changed his will, that would have been a factor warranting a review of his mental state and likely would have resulted in him being placed back on suicide watch.
The interview was conducted by FBI agents and Assistant U.S. Attorneys for the Southern District of New York as part of the investigation into Epstein's death.
